lesson.title: Sequencing Events - Async/Await
lesson.summary: This lesson will get you acquainted with the Async/Await syntax introduced in ES8. Let's master the code and principles behind this helpful addition designed to make asynchronous flows easier.

atoms.text:
## Sequencing Events with Async/await

### Overview

atoms.title: ND032 JSND L3 A01 Introduction V2

atoms.text:
## Concepts
In this lesson we will cover the following:

- Review of JavaScript Try/Catch blocks
- Introduction to Async/await
- Using Async/await with promises
- Async/await error handling
- When (and when not) to use Async/await

### Resources
Here is a list of supporting resources you might find helpful as you start this lesson:
- A good all-around review from Toptal: [Asynchronous JavaScript: From Callback Hell to Async and Await](https://www.toptal.com/javascript/asynchronous-javascript-async-await-tutorial)
- The MDN guide: [Making asynchronous programming easier with async and await](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/Asynchronous/Async_await)

# The Foundations of Async/Await

Before we get started with the Async/await syntax, it will be helpful to take a look at some synchronous syntax - the Try/catch block of vanilla JavaScript. In this lesson we will cover custom error handling with Try/catch because it will come in handy later as we learn the Async/await syntax.

## Try/Catch Blocks

atoms.title: ND032 JSND L3 A02 Try Catch Blocks

atoms.text: ### Give Try/Catch A Try!
## Solution Walkthrough

atoms.title: ND032 JSND L3 A03 Solution Try Catch Practice

atoms.text:
# The Purpose of Async/Await

### Why Do We Need More Syntax?

atoms.title: ND032 JSND L3 A04 Why Do We Need More Syntax

atoms.text:
## Video Recap

When you need to do operations that involve the results of more than one Promise, it is difficult to make that operation wait to run until all the Promises have resolved and the values are ready. Async/await helps us get around this difficulty by giving us the power to turn Promises into **blocking** operations when we want to. 

Experiment with this code example from the video to see why doing operations with the results of asynchronous Promises can be difficult:

## Introduction to Async/Await 

### The Syntax

Here is an example of the Async/Await syntax.

Some things I want you to notice here are that:
- we are still using Promises
- the `async` word before the function declaration
- the `await` word before the function call that returns a Promise

Don't worry if this example doesn't totally make sense yet, we'll go over all of this and more in the next video.

### Introduction

atoms.title: ND032 JSND L3 A05 Intro To Async Await

atoms.text: ## Error Handling with Async/Await

atoms.title: ND032 JSND L3 A06 Error Handling With Async Await

atoms.text:
## Error Handling in Async/await Recap

Another benefit of the synchronous behavior we get when using Async/await, is that it allows us to use the `try`/`catch` exception handling syntax we learned at the beginning of this lesson. You can also handle `async` functions with the `.catch` style error handling we saw with Promises, but it is more common to see the `try`/`catch` syntax used with Async/await. This means that all of the principles we learned about custom error handling with synchronous JavaScript can now apply to our asynchronous flows as well!

### Try It Out

You can run the code from the video in the Workspace below.  Which type of error handling do you prefer?

concepts.title: When (and When Not) to Use Async/Await

atoms.text: ##  When (and When Not) to Use Async/Await

atoms.title: ND032 JSND L3 A07 When And When Not To Use Async Await V2

atoms.text:
## Video Recap

#### You should use Async/Await when:
- The results from multiple Promises will  be used together.
- You need perform a lot of logic after one or multiple Promises resolve
- Logic in a synchronous-style function would be cleaner than in a `.then` chain (this is mostly personal preference)

#### You shouldn't use Async/Await if:
- You don't need to use the `await` word in the function
- You just want the function to return a promise (instead use Promise.new from the promises lesson)

#### Think carefully about using Async/Await because:
- It will change the output of the function. If other parts of the program rely on the output of that function, changing it to `async` will have unexpected consequences
## Async/Await Quizzes

complex_prompt.text: Try/Catch is the traditional way to handle errors, Promise chains also handle errors too and uses slightly different syntax to cover the same situations. Match the Try/Catch syntax with the Promise syntax that performs the same function

question.prompt: When the logic of an `async` function is wrapped in Try/catch blocks and one of the awaited Promises rejects, Try/catch treats the rejected Promise:

answers.text: In the same way `Promise.allSettled` does, by marking that Promise as rejected in the resulting array
In the same way as `Promise.race` does, by passing along any data that came with the rejected Promise
In the same way as Try/Catch blocks treat errors thrown by JavaScript, meaning the `catch` statement will run
A, B, C, E, F, G

question.prompt: Select the benefits of using Async/await syntax from the list below.

answers.text: Allows us to not use Promises anymore
Allows us to select Promises to be treated as blocking actions with the async word
Allows us to select Promises to be treated as blocking actions with the await word
Allows the developer to write all their asynchronous functionality with callbacks
Allows the developer to use the results of many Promises and be confident that the Promises have resolved

question.prompt: Explain when you would use Async/await in JavaScript.

atoms.text:
## Async/Await Conclusion

Congratulations! You finished the Async/await lesson and the last of the course content.

atoms.title: ND032 JSND L3 A08 Lesson Conclusion V2

atoms.text:
### Lesson Concepts Recap

Congratulations on wrapping up the last lesson in this course! Here's a look back at all we've done. 
- Try/Catch syntax and exception handling 
-  Async/Await syntax
-  Async/Await uses and concepts
-  Async/Await use cases

### Resources for Further Research
- For another look at Try/Catch and exception handling, here is a good resource: [JavaScript trycatch Statement](https://www.javascripttutorial.net/javascript-try-catch/)
- The MDN Async/Await resource: [Making asynchronous programming easier with async and await](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/Asynchronous/Async_await)

## Course Recap

You have completed the course work for Asynchronous Programming with JavaScript! We have come a long way and learned so many new terms and concepts from synchronous code all the way to Async/await. You have accomplished a lot - take a moment to celebrate! Here is a look at all the lessons we covered in this course:

atoms.title: ND032 JSND L3 A09 Course Recap V2

atoms.text:
## Congratulations!

Completing this course is a big accomplishment and you've taken a huge step forward in your skills as a developer. I have enjoyed developing this course and I hope that the material was both challenging and helpful for you, and that you find the skills and concepts you learned these lessons to be beneficial in your day to day work. Like I said at the very beginning of the course, the concepts we learned are incredibly important for moving forward in your career as a developer and they will take practice to truly master. So I will leave you now with your first opportunity to practice these concepts on your own in the project. Happy racing and good luck!
